column2: locally: [ˈɡena]; Coptic: ⲕⲱⲛⲏ Kone) is a city in Upper Egypt
column3: and the capital of the Qena Governorate. Situated on the east bank of the Nile
column4: it was known in antiquity as Kaine (Greek Καινή
column5: meaning "new (city)"; Latinized transliteration: Caene) and Maximianopolis. Gauthier identifies Qena with ancient Shabt.

column1: This provincial capital is located about 57 miles from El Balyana and 39 miles north of Luxor. It is most famous for its proximity to the ruins of Dendara. It owes its modern prosperity to the opening of the Wadi Qena towards the Red Sea
column2: which is a major traffic route between Upper Egypt and the Red Sea. Tourists traveling between Luxor and the Red Sea will assuredly pass through this city since there is only one good road connection. Qena is noted for its pottery. Qena is also known for its beautiful huge mountains and green nature.

column1: Qena also has one of the highest concentration of Coptic Christians in Egypt (approximately 35% of the total population).
In addition to its Ancient Egyptian heritage as the city of Caenepolis. Qena has a considerable Islamic heritage and many unique architectural mosques. Qena has witnessed major restorations
column2: and came third in the UNESCO City Beauty contest.

column1: Qena has a hot desert climate (BWh) according to Köppen climate classification
column2: with very hot summers and very little precipitation year round. Winters are warm at days
column3: but become cool at nights. The hottest months on average are equally July and August
column4: while the coolest month is January. Luxor
column6: Qena and Asyut have the widest difference of temperatures between days and nights of any city in Egypt

column1: The hottest temperature recorded was on May 15
column2: 1991 which was 50 °C (122 °F) and the coldest temperature was on January 6

column1: Qena has a network of streets
column2: roads and highways with greenery and flowered pavements. From the city there is a road that crosses the Eastern Desert to port Safaga on the Red Sea.

column1: The United States Air Force conducted classified operations from Wadi Qena airfield from the 1970s to the 1990s
column2: under the code names Coronet Scabbard
column5: and Coronet Mallard. The 4401st Combat Support Squadron (Provisional) maintained a near-constant CENTAF presence there. Part of these operations probably included Lockheed MC-130 flights during the Desert One rescue attempts for the U.S. hostages in Tehran in the late 1970s.
